title: Practitioner Research and Practice-Near Methods
abstractText:
This seminar series aims to address current priorities for the development and enhancement of social work research. It is designed as a collaborative venture, in conjunction with users and stakeholders from a wide range of organisations and user groups. Four one-day seminars and a concluding two-days conference will provide a setting through which currently separate strands of thinking can be drawn together, synthesised and further developed. The aims and objectives for the seminars include:

  • Raising awareness and standing of practitioner research for developing social work research capacity
  • Exploring the challenges and opportunities in newer qualitative methodologies that have particular potential for researching relationship-based practice
  • Identifying ‘practice-near’ methodologies and considering the role of these in the context of Evidence Based Practice (EBP)
  • Exploring the infrastructure requirements for the development of practitioner research

Programme: One-day seminars:

  • 15 or 16 January 2007, Lancashire: Narrative, biographical and life history approaches to research
  • 16 March 2007, London: Infant observation and its applications
  • 2 June 2007, London: Case-based research: researching direct work with service users
  • 5 November 2007, London: Evaluative research: qualitative and relational approaches 
  • January/February 2008, Lancashire: Concluding 2 day conference.
